mn65:3.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī, in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
mn65:3.3: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants:
mn65:4.1: “Mendicants, I eat my food in one sitting per day.
mn65:4.2: Doing so, I find that I’m healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.
mn65:4.3: You too should eat your food in one sitting per day.
mn65:4.4: Doing so, you’ll find that you’re healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.”
mn65:5.1: When he said this, Venerable Sāriputta asked the Buddha:
mn65:5.2: “Sir, I’m not going to try to eat my food in one sitting per day.
mn65:5.3: For when eating once a day I might feel remorse and regret.”
mn65:5.4: “Well then, Bhaddāli, eat one part of the meal in the place where you’re invited, and bring the rest back to eat.
mn65:5.5: Eating this way, too, you will sustain yourself.”
mn65:5.6: “Sir, I’m not going to try to eat that way, either.
mn65:5.7: For when eating that way I might also feel remorse and regret.”
mn65:5.8: Then, as this rule was being laid down by the Buddha and the Saṅgha was undertaking it, Bhaddāli announced he would not try to keep it.
mn65:5.9: Then for the whole of that three months Bhaddāli did not present himself in the presence of the Buddha, as happens when someone doesn’t fulfill the training according to the Teacher’s instructions.
mn65:6.1: At that time several mendicants were making a robe for the Buddha, thinking that
mn65:6.2: when his robe was finished and the three months of the rains residence had passed the Buddha would set out wandering.
mn65:6.3: Then Bhaddāli went up to those mendicants,
mn65:6.5: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side.
mn65:6.7: “Reverend Bhaddāli, this robe is being made for the Buddha.
mn65:6.8: When it’s finished and the three months of the rains residence have passed the Buddha will set out wandering.
mn65:6.9: Come on, Bhaddāli, learn your lesson. Don’t make it hard for yourself later on.”
mn65:6.10: “Yes, reverends,” Bhaddāli replied. He went to the Buddha,
mn65:6.11: bowed, sat down to one side,
mn65:6.13: “I have made a mistake, sir. It was foolish, stupid, and unskillful of me that, as this rule was being laid down by the Buddha and the Saṅgha was undertaking it, I announced I would not try to keep it.
mn65:6.14: Please, sir, accept my mistake for what it is, so I will restrain myself in future.”
mn65:7.1: “Indeed, Bhaddāli, you made a mistake. It was foolish, stupid, and unskillful of you that, as this rule was being laid down by the Buddha and the Saṅgha was undertaking it, you announced you would not try to keep it.
mn65:7.2: And you didn’t realize this situation:
mn65:7.3: ‘The Buddha is staying in Sāvatthī, and he’ll know me
mn65:7.4: as the mendicant named Bhaddāli who doesn’t fulfill the training according to the Teacher’s instructions.’
mn65:7.6: And you didn’t realize this situation:
mn65:7.7: ‘Many monks have entered the rains retreat in Sāvatthī …
mn65:7.11: many nuns have entered the rains retreat in Sāvatthī …
mn65:7.19: many laywomen reside in Sāvatthī, and they’ll know me
mn65:7.20: as the mendicant named Bhaddāli who doesn’t fulfill the training according to the Teacher’s instructions. …
mn65:7.23: Several ascetics and brahmins who follow various other paths have entered the rains retreat in Sāvatthī, and they’ll know me
mn65:7.24: as the mendicant named Bhaddāli, one of the senior disciples of Gotama, who doesn’t fulfill the training according to the Teacher’s instructions.’
mn65:7.25: You also didn’t realize this situation.”
mn65:8.1: “I made a mistake, sir. It was foolish, stupid, and unskillful of me that, as this rule was being laid down by the Buddha and the Saṅgha was undertaking it, I announced I would not try to keep it.
mn65:8.2: Please, sir, accept my mistake for what it is, so I will restrain myself in future.”
mn65:9.1: “Indeed, Bhaddāli, you made a mistake. It was foolish, stupid, and unskillful of you that, as this rule was being laid down by the Buddha and the Saṅgha was undertaking it, you announced you would not try to keep it.
mn65:10.1: What do you think, Bhaddāli? Suppose I was to say this to a mendicant who is freed both ways:
mn65:10.2: ‘Please, mendicant, be a bridge for me to cross over the mud.’ Would they cross over themselves, or struggle to get out of it, or just say no?”
mn65:12.1: “What do you think, Bhaddāli? Suppose I was to say the same thing to a mendicant who is freed by wisdom,
mn65:12.7: ‘Please, mendicant, be a bridge for me to cross over the mud.’ Would they cross over themselves, or struggle to get out of it, or just say no?”
mn65:14.1: “What do you think, Bhaddāli? At that time were you freed both ways, freed by wisdom, a direct witness, attained to view, freed by faith, a follower of principle, or a follower by faith?”
mn65:17.3: Please, sir, accept my mistake for what it is, so I will restrain myself in future.”
mn65:18.2: But since you have recognized your mistake for what it is, and have dealt with it properly, I accept it.
mn65:18.3: For it is growth in the training of the noble one to recognize a mistake for what it is, deal with it properly, and commit to restraint in the future.
mn65:19.1: Bhaddāli, take a mendicant who doesn’t fulfill the training according to the Teacher’s instructions.
mn65:19.3: ‘Why don’t I frequent a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw.
mn65:19.4: Hopefully I’ll realize a superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones.’
mn65:19.5: So he frequents a secluded lodging.
mn65:19.6: While they’re living withdrawn, they’re reprimanded by the Teacher, by sensible spiritual companions after examination, by gods, and by themselves.
mn65:19.7: Being reprimanded in this way, they don’t realize any superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones.
mn65:19.9: Because that’s how it is when someone doesn’t fulfill the training according to the Teacher’s instructions.
mn65:20.1: But take a mendicant who does fulfill the training according to the Teacher’s instructions.
mn65:20.3: ‘Why don’t I frequent a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw.
mn65:20.4: Hopefully I’ll realize a superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones.’
mn65:20.5: They frequent a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw.
mn65:20.6: While they’re living withdrawn, they’re not reprimanded by the Teacher, by sensible spiritual companions after examination, by gods, or by themselves.
mn65:20.7: Not being reprimanded in this way, they realize a superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones.
mn65:20.8: Quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unwholesome qualities, they enter and remain in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
mn65:20.10: Because that’s what happens when someone fulfills the training according to the Teacher’s instructions.
mn65:21.1: Furthermore, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, a mendicant enters and remains in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of samādhi, with internal clarity and confidence, and oneness of mind, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.
mn65:21.3: Because that’s what happens when someone fulfills the training according to the Teacher’s instructions.
mn65:22.1: Furthermore, with the fading away of rapture, a mendicant enters and remains in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss’.
mn65:22.4: Because that’s what happens when someone fulfills the training according to the Teacher’s instructions.
mn65:23.1: Furthermore, giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, a mendicant enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.
mn65:23.3: Because that’s what happens when someone fulfills the training according to the Teacher’s instructions.
mn65:24.1: When their mind has converged in samādhi like this—purified, bright, spotless, rid of taints, pliable, workable, steady, and motionless—they turn it toward recollection of past lives.
mn65:24.2: They recollect many kinds of past lives, that is,
mn65:24.3: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand lives; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world evolving, many eons of the world contracting and evolving. …
mn65:24.5: They recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
mn65:24.7: Because that’s what happens when someone fulfills the training according to the Teacher’s instructions.
mn65:25.1: When their mind has converged in samādhi like this—purified, bright, spotless, rid of taints, pliable, workable, steady, and motionless—they turn it toward knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings.
mn65:25.2: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds:
mn65:25.3: ‘These dear beings, alas, did bad things by way of body, speech, and mind. …
mn65:25.5: They’re reborn in the underworld, hell.
mn65:25.6: These dear beings, however, did good things by way of body, speech, and mind. …
mn65:25.8: they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.’ And so, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman …
mn65:25.10: they understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds.
mn65:25.12: Because that’s what happens when someone fulfills the training according to the Teacher’s instructions.
mn65:26.1: When his mind has converged in samādhi like this—purified, bright, spotless, rid of taints, pliable, workable, steady, and motionless—he turns it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements.
mn65:26.2: They truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.
mn65:26.3: They truly understand: ‘These are defilements’ … ‘This is the origin of defilements’ … ‘This is the cessation of defilements’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of defilements’.
mn65:26.4: Knowing and seeing like this, their mind is freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire for rebirth, and ignorance.
mn65:26.5: When freed, they know ‘it is freed’.
mn65:26.6: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’
mn65:26.8: Because that’s what happens when someone fulfills the training according to the Teacher’s instructions.”
mn65:27.1: When he said this, Venerable Bhaddāli asked the Buddha:
mn65:27.2: “What is the cause, sir, what is the reason why they punish some monk, repeatedly pressuring him?
mn65:27.3: And what is the cause, what is the reason why they don’t similarly punish another monk, repeatedly pressuring him?”
mn65:28.1: “Take a monk who is a frequent offender with many offences.
mn65:28.2: When admonished by the mendicants, he dodges the issue, distracting the discussion with irrelevant points. He displays irritation, hate, and bitterness. He doesn’t proceed properly, he doesn’t fall in line, he doesn’t proceed to get past it, and he doesn’t say: ‘I’ll do what pleases the Saṅgha.’
mn65:28.3: In such a case, the monks think:
mn65:28.4: ‘This monk is a frequent offender, with many offences.
mn65:28.5: When admonished by the mendicants, he dodges the issue, distracting the discussion with irrelevant points. He displays irritation, hate, and bitterness. He doesn’t proceed properly, he doesn’t fall in line, he doesn’t proceed to get past it, and he doesn’t say: “I’ll do what pleases the Saṅgha.”
mn65:28.6: It’d be good for the venerables to examine this monk in such a way that this disciplinary issue is not quickly settled.’
mn65:29.1: Take some other monk who is a frequent offender with many offences.
mn65:29.2: When admonished by the mendicants, he doesn’t dodge the issue, distracting the discussion with irrelevant points. He doesn’t display irritation, hate, and bitterness. He proceeds properly, he falls in line, he proceeds to get past it, and he says: ‘I’ll do what pleases the Saṅgha.’
mn65:29.3: In such a case, the monks say:
mn65:29.4: ‘Reverends, this monk is a frequent offender, with many offences.
mn65:29.5: When admonished by the mendicants, he doesn’t dodge the issue, distracting the discussion with irrelevant points. He doesn’t display irritation, hate, and bitterness. He proceeds properly, he falls in line, he proceeds to get past it, and he says: ‘I’ll do what pleases the Saṅgha.’
mn65:29.6: It’d be good for the venerables to examine this monk in such a way that this disciplinary issue is quickly settled.’
mn65:30.1: Take some other monk who is an occasional offender without many offences.
mn65:30.2: When admonished by the mendicants, he dodges the issue …
mn65:30.3: In such a case, the monks say:
mn65:30.4: ‘Reverends, this monk is an occasional offender without many offences.
mn65:30.5: When admonished by the mendicants, he dodges the issue …
mn65:30.6: It’d be good for the venerables to examine this monk in such a way that this disciplinary issue is not quickly settled.’
mn65:31.1: Take some other monk who is an occasional offender without many offences.
mn65:31.2: When admonished by the mendicants, he doesn’t dodge the issue …
mn65:31.3: In such a case, the monks say:
mn65:31.4: ‘Reverends, this monk is an occasional offender without many offences.
mn65:31.5: When admonished by the mendicants, he doesn’t dodge the issue …
mn65:31.6: It’d be good for the venerables to examine this monk in such a way that this disciplinary issue is quickly settled.’
mn65:32.1: Take some other monk who gets by with mere faith and love.
mn65:32.2: In such a case, the monks say:
mn65:32.3: ‘Reverends, this monk gets by with mere faith and love.
mn65:32.4: If we punish him, repeatedly pressuring him—
mn65:32.5: no, let him not lose what little faith and love he has!’
mn65:32.6: Suppose there was a person with one eye. Their friends and colleagues, relatives and kin would protect that one eye:
mn65:32.7: ‘Let them not lose the one eye that they have!’
mn65:32.8: In the same way, some monk gets by with mere faith and love.
mn65:32.9: In such a case, the monks say:
mn65:32.10: ‘Reverends, this monk gets by with mere faith and love.
mn65:32.11: If we punish him, repeatedly pressuring him—
mn65:32.12: no, let him not lose what little faith and love he has!’
mn65:32.13: This is the cause, this is the reason why they punish some monk, repeatedly pressuring him.
mn65:32.14: And this is the cause, this is the reason why they don’t similarly punish another monk, repeatedly pressuring him.”
mn65:33.1: “What is the cause, sir, what is the reason why there used to be fewer training rules but more enlightened mendicants?
mn65:33.2: And what is the cause, what is the reason why these days there are more training rules and fewer enlightened mendicants?”
mn65:34.1: “That’s how it is, Bhaddāli. When sentient beings are in decline and the true teaching is disappearing there are more training rules and fewer enlightened mendicants.
mn65:34.2: The Teacher doesnʼt lay down training rules for disciples as long as certain defiling influences have not appeared in the Saṅgha.
mn65:34.3: But when such defiling influences appear in the Saṅgha, the Teacher lays down training rules for disciples to protect against them.
mn65:34.4: And they donʼt appear until the Saṅgha has attained a great size,
mn65:34.7: an abundance of material support and fame, learning, and seniority.
mn65:34.8: But when the Saṅgha has attained these things, then such defiling influences appear in the Saṅgha, and the Teacher lays down training rules for disciples to protect against them.
mn65:35.1: There were only of few of you there at the time when I taught the explanation of the teaching on the simile of the thoroughbred colt.
mn65:37.1: “What do you believe the reason for that is?”
mn65:38.1: “Sir, it’s surely because for a long time now I haven’t fulfilled the training according to the Teacher’s instructions.”
mn65:39.2: Rather, for a long time I have comprehended your mind and known:
mn65:39.3: ‘While I’m teaching, this foolish man doesn’t pay attention, focus, concentrate, or listen well.’
mn65:39.4: Still, Bhaddāli, I shall teach the explanation of the teaching on the simile of the thoroughbred colt.
mn65:40.1: “Suppose an expert horse trainer were to obtain a fine thoroughbred. First of all he’d make it get used to wearing the bit.
mn65:40.2: Because it has not done this before, it still resorts to some tricks, dodges, and evasions.
mn65:40.3: But with regular and gradual practice it quells that bad habit.
mn65:40.4: When it has done this, the horse trainer next makes it get used to wearing the harness.
mn65:40.5: Because it has not done this before, it still resorts to some tricks, dodges, and evasions.
mn65:40.6: But with regular and gradual practice it quells that bad habit.
mn65:40.7: When it has done this, the horse trainer next makes it get used to walking in procession, circling, prancing, galloping, charging, the protocols and traditions of court, and in the very best speed, fleetness, and friendliness.
mn65:40.8: Because it has not done this before, it still resorts to some tricks, dodges, and evasions.
mn65:40.9: But with regular and gradual practice it quells that bad habit.
mn65:40.10: When it has done this, the horse trainer next rewards it with a grooming and a rub down.
mn65:40.11: A fine royal thoroughbred with these ten factors is worthy of a king, fit to serve a king, and considered a factor of kingship.
mn65:41.1: In the same way, a mendicant with ten qualities is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a teacher’s offering, worthy of veneration with folded palms, and is a supreme field of merit for the world.
mn65:41.3: It’s when a mendicant has a master’s right view, right motivation, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right mindfulness, right samādhi, right knowledge, and right freedom.
mn65:41.4: A mendicant with these ten factors is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a teacher’s offering, worthy of veneration with folded palms, and is a supreme field of merit for the world.”
mn65:42.1: This is what the Buddha said.
mn65:42.2: Uplifted, Venerable Tissa approved of what the Buddha said.
